Live Forecast:WI 200

Report

Evin Lewis was out injured for the hosts, who hope to give Andre Russell the perfect send off

Toss Australia opt to bowl vs West Indies

Mitchell Owen will make his T20I debut for Australia in the first T20I against West Indies in Kingston after a stunning BBL season but will bat an No. 6 rather than at the top, where he made his name for Hobart Hurricanes.

Owen might get a bowl before he bats in T20I cricket after Australia opted to bowl first under lights at Sabina Park in the first of a five-match series.

Meanwhile, Evin Lewis was out injured as Brandon King returned to the top of the order to open alongside skipper Shai Hope. Andre Russell is listed at No. 7 in his penultimate T20I for West Indies while Sherfane Rutherford is back in the middle order after missing the UK tour. West Indies opted for two specialist left-arm orthodox spinners in Gudakesh Motie and Akeal Hosein.

Jake Fraser-McGurk, who was a late addition to Australia's squad as wicketkeeping cover for Josh Inglis, will open alongside Mitchell Marsh as Travis Head was rested from the series. Matt Short also flew home with a minor side strain.

Tim David has been ruled out of the first game of the series as he is not quite ready to play following his long recovery from a hamstring injury he suffered in the IPL. He is expected to be fit for game two, though, on Tuesday. Cooper Connolly has been named to bat at No. 7, and provide an extra spin option with Australia opting to pick three fast bowlers and one specialist spinner in Adam Zampa. Nathan Ellis will lead the seam attack alongside Sean Abbott and Ben Dwarshuis, with Pat Cummins, Josh Hazlewood and Mitchell Starc all unavailable for the entire series after flying home to rest following the Test series.

West Indies: 1 Brandon King, 2 Shai Hope (capt/wk), 3 Roston Chase, 4 Shimron Hetmyer, 5 Rovman Powell, 6 Sherfane Rutherford, 7 Andre Russell, 8 Jason Holder, 9 Gudakesh Motie, 10 Akeal Hosein, 11 Alzarri Joseph

Australia: 1 Mitchell Marsh (capt), 2 Jake Fraser-McGurk, 3 Josh Inglis (wk), 4 Cameron Green, 5 Glenn Maxwell, 6 Mitchell Owen, 7 Cooper Connolly, 8 Ben Dwarshius, 9 Sean Abbott, 10 Nathan Ellis, 11 Adam Zampa

Alex Malcolm is an associate editor at ESPNcricinfo
